body:
Hi,

Hopefully it's not hard to get this information.
Can we just treat these as expressions and place them in the `expressions` list?
Forgot to ping @zzzeek in the above question
ok, so the only thing to add would be the actual reflection of these

rename.from: Postgres: Reflection of indexes with opperators
rename.to: Postgres: Reflection of indexes with operators

issue.title: Reflect index's column operator class on PostgreSQL
issue.body:
Fill the `postgresql_ops` key of PostgreSQL's `dialect_options` returned by get_multi_indexes() with a mapping from column names to the operator class, if it's not the default for respective data type.

As we need to join on ``pg_catalog.pg_opclass``, the table definition is added to ``postgresql.pg_catalog``.

Fixes #8664.

body: In https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/pull/12504, I suggest to reflect the operator classes in `postgresql_ops` key of `dialect_options`, as this would be symmetrical to the index definition. It seems better than using `expressions` as suggested earlier here, no?

**Denis Laxalde** has proposed a fix for this issue in the **main** branch:

**Reflect index's column operator class on PostgreSQL** https://gerrit.sqlalchemy.org/c/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/+/5897

**Denis Laxalde** has proposed a fix for this issue in the **rel_2_0** branch:

**Reflect index's column operator class on PostgreSQL** https://gerrit.sqlalchemy.org/c/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/+/5898

Much thanks! 

I'm going to have a go at fixing https://github.com/sqlalchemy/alembic/issues/1098 now
